description: From Middle English rein, reyne, borrowed from Anglo-Norman reyne, resne, from early Medieval Latin retina, ultimately from Classical Latin retineō (“hold back”), from re- + teneō (“keep, hold”). Compare modern French rêne.
Displaced native Old English ġewealdleþer (literally “control leather”).

entries.meaning: A strap or rope attached to a bridle or bit, used to control a horse, animal or young child.
(figurative) An instrument or means of curbing, restraining, or governing.

verbs.description: rein (third-person singular simple present reins, present participle reining, simple past and past participle reined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To direct or stop a horse by using reins.
(transitive) To restrain; to control; to check.
examples: After an interval that he judged to have lasted twenty minutes, the bed began to shake with poorly reined sobs.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To obey directions given with the reins.
examples: She worked each horse at a walk, trot, and then a canter. The horses reined well and executed stops quickly.

description: From Anglo-Norman reines, Middle French reins, and their source, Latin rēnēs. Doublet of ren.

entries.meaning: (now rare, archaic, chiefly in plural) A kidney.
The inward impulses; the affections and passions, formerly supposed to be located in the area of the kidneys.
